newsitem.title: INDIA: Punters, local funds drive Bombay shares higher.
newsitem.headline: Punters, local funds drive Bombay shares higher.

text.p: Share prices held smart gains at close on Tuesday as sentiment improved after the weekend's new credit policy which released impounded bank funds, dealers said.
"The sentiment got a shot in the arm," said Bharat Dhanki at broking firm Vrajlal Dhanki. "The credit policy was very good."

As part of its monetary policy for the second half of 1996/97 (April-March), the central bank on Saturday cut reserve requirements for banks and reduced the interest cap on short-term deposits which sparked cuts in prime lending rates.
The 30-share Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) index rose 98.75 points, or 3.15 percent, to a provisional 3,228.96.
The 50-stock National Stock Exchange (NSE) ended 28.32 points, or 3.16 percent, higher at a provisional 923.32.
The bourses were closed on Monday for a national holiday.
Traders said the market was driven up by local punters and mutual funds. Foreign institutions booked profit in some stocks but bought into state-run firms and other blue-chip stocks.
"There was heavy buying in index-linked stocks," Dhanki said. "It was a trader's market."
He said investment demand was largely limited to purchases by domestic funds.

SBI and Reliance rallied 10 rupees each, to 228.75 and 206.75 respectively. Bajaj Auto rose 32.50 rupees to 971.50, Indian Hotels 27.75 to 631.25, L&T 19.0 to 234, Grasim 16.5 to 432.25, TELCO 8.0 to 430 and TISCO 2.75 to 175.25 at the BSE.
Analysts expect the upsurge to push the BSE index up by another 100 points but see resistance building up.
"I don't think this (the rally) will be sustained," Amish Choksi at broker Nalinkant Dalal said.
"We have to wait for the (half-year company) results. These are not going to be very good."
